												Good game. Has few flaws, but it is certainly not bad. All 3 races are different, but also look familiar to the zerg-protoss-terran stuff. Still game feels unique. You can also control the commander in 3rd person!And last thing. Steam says it is SP only. But there is LAN (online service was shut down ages ago) still have'nt tested it, but it should work well. It's a good game if you like RTS, and is worth the money especially on sale.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												Good:very unique, fun gameplay that I havent seen in an RTS before.AI can build your base for you while you focus on the combat.the three races are suprisingly different from one-another.The terrian is dynamic, and can be manipulated to build walls, ditches, and foxholes.Bad:Some players need to use a glitch just to get to the main menu.Everyone in the game moves at half the speed of smell.One of the races (ascension) has a completely broken AI.Ascension takes forever to get the cool units.The direct control ability, where you take direct control of a hero unit as a third-person shooter is god-aweful.The most important resource, water, takes forever to get despite most of the battles taking place near the ocean.Conclusion: an interesting game with too many flaws to make it "good"  Definitely worth picking up if you can find it for cheap.  Anything over $5 is too much.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
												I'm surprised Steam managed to get this working.SummaryMaelstrom: The Battle for Earth Begins is a Real-Time Strategy/Third-Person Shooter hybrid developed by KD-Vision Games in Russia, published by Codemasters, and released in 2007.The game takes place in 2057 where corporations rose to power and caused a nuclear war.The resulting climate change has rendered much of the planet inhospitable to human life.Within this chaos, three forces battle out for control of the Earth.The Remnants are the rebel forces of those who still fight for freedom and justice.The Ascension are an imperialistic collective of corporations ruled by Arlan Khan.The Hai-Genti are an alien race that seeks to conquer Earth after destroying their homeworld.ProsThe game features two unique mechanics known as terraforming and weather control, which allow players to transform entire maps at will, provided they have enough resources.The voice acting is fairly decent, although the unit voices are rather annoying.It has an original story and all of the characters are quite memorable.ConsAs one might expect from a game made in 2007, its graphics are significantly outdated and the CD version is incompatible with any operating systems made after Windows 95/XP/Vista.The Steam version is merely a bypass to this incompatibility, but there are consequences.There are two crippling bugs that cause the game to crash consistently.These bugs occur at random and there's no autosave, so if you get this game, SAVE OFTEN.The first bug occurs between transitions such as loading screens and cutscenes.The game will freeze and any audio playing at that moment will skip like a broken record.The second bug occurs during gameplay, especially when using the Third-Person mechanic.The game will suddenly stop and exit automatically without any notification.ConclusionThere's not much to say about this game, it's really fun but time has left it on life support.KDV Games is defunct and Codemasters disowned the game by taking it off their website.Because of this, this game is abandonware, which means anyone has the opportunity to remaster it and breathe life back into the series, especially since its ending suggests a sequel.

number of helpful: 14 of 33 people (42%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												While this game does have some interesting things they tried to do, I feel that it has lost in some of the most basic elements of an RTS.  Whether this is a result of lack of polish or overemphasis on a few key features, the result is a game that just feels weak.  Leaving aside cinematics, vocals and dialog, from the very beginning, the command UI feels frustrating.  There is no feeling of control over an engagement; your infantry will wander around and do whatever they want.  They'll watch complacently while a teammate is mowed down five feet away, and one guy will take a jog around three sides of a building to rejoin the squad after you moved them to an adjacent corner.  Any attempt at strategy is pointless, and blobbing soldiers is really the only thing you can do.  The game's age isn't an excuse; there are many games much older than this one that have better playability.  The Ground Control series comes to mind.
